title: Equality
target: The story takes up immediately after the events of Looking Backward with the main characters from the first novel, Julian West, Doctor Leete, and his daughter Edith. West tells his nightmare of return to the 19th century to Edith, who is sympathetic. West's citizenship in the new America is recognized, and he goes to the bank to obtain his own account, or "credit card", from which he can draw on the annual stipend all citizens receive. He learns that Edith and her mother do not normally wear the long skirts he has seen them in (they have been wearing them so his 19th century sensibilities will not be shocked), and when Edith learns that he would not be shocked to see them dressed otherwise, immediately runs into the house and comes out dressed as a modern woman in a pants suit. Clothing varies widely, since it is made of strengthened paper, and is recycled when dirty and replaced at very small expense (shoes and dishes are made of variations on the same substance). Julian learns that women are free to compete in many of the same trades as men; the manager of the paper factory he goes to view is a woman. Edith herself is in the second year of the three year general labor period required of everyone before choosing a trade, but is on leave from that employment. The two tour a tenement house, in which no one now lives, kept as a reminder of things how used to be and a reminder not to go back to them. Julian opens his safe (a device unknown in 2000 outside museums). Dr. Leete sees his mortgages and securities not as long-obsolete claims to ownership interest in things, but rather in people and their labor. The papers are worthless except as antiquities, as most of such papers were burned at the conclusion of the economic transition, in a great blaze on the former site of the New York Stock Exchange. The gold coins in the safe are admired for their prettiness, but are also worthless. Julian learns more about the world of the year 2000. Handwriting has been virtually replaced by phonograph records, and jewelry is no longer used, since jewels are now worthless. Julian is amazed by a television-like device, called the electroscope. World communication is simplified, since everyone now speaks a universal language in addition to his native tongue. Not only are there motor cars, but also private air cars. Everyone is now vegetarian, and the thought of eating meat is looked upon with revulsion. The book concludes with an almost uninterrupted series of lectures from Dr. Leete and other characters, mostly concerning how the idyllic state West has arrived in was achieved.
pred: Charles Dudley Warner presents a new edition of his book, entitled Equality. The book begins with the premise that all humans are created "altered." This is not to be confused with the concept of equality; it's just that there are inequalities inherent in human nature. In fact, according to Darwinist scholar John Morell, economic theory and social theory developed during the eighteenth-century under the leadership of Henry Louisa May Alcott. Sociologists have argued for more than a century that this age should attempt to rediscover the concepts of equality--equality of opportunity, civil society, freedom of choice, and political freedom. They argue that these ideas must be redrafted so that they no longer conflict with the scientific theories of earlier generations. advertisement

title: A Passage to India
target: A young British schoolmistress, Adela Quested, and her elderly friend, Mrs. Moore, visit the fictional city of Chandrapore, British India. Adela is to marry Mrs. Moore's son, Ronny Heaslop, the city magistrate. Meanwhile, Dr. Aziz, a young Indian Muslim physician, is dining with two of his Indian friends and conversing about whether it is possible to be friends with an Englishman. During the meal, a summons arrives from Major Callendar, Aziz's unpleasant superior at the hospital. Aziz hastens to Callendar's bungalow as ordered, but is delayed by a flat tyre and difficulty in finding a tonga and the major has already left in a huff. Disconsolate, Aziz walks down the road toward the railway station. When he sees his favourite mosque, a rather ramshackle but beautiful structure, he enters on impulse. He sees a strange Englishwoman there, and angrily yells at her not to profane this sacred place. The woman, who turns out to be Mrs Moore, has respect for native customs (she had taken off her shoes before entering and she acknowledged that "God is here" in the mosque) disarms Aziz, and the two chat and part as friends. Mrs. Moore returns to the British club down the road and relates her experience at the mosque. Ronny Heaslop, her son, initially thinks she is talking about an Englishman, and becomes indignant when he learns the facts. He thinks she should have indicated by her tone that it was a "Mohammedan" who was in question. Adela, however, is intrigued. Because the newcomers had expressed a desire to see Indians, Mr. Turton, the city tax collector, invites numerous Indian gentlemen to a party at his house. The party turns out to be an awkward business, thanks to the Indians' timidity and the Britons' bigotry, but Adela does meet Cyril Fielding, headmaster of Chandrapore's government-run college for Indians. Fielding invites Adela and Mrs. Moore to a tea party with him and a Hindu-Brahmin professor named Narayan Godbole. On Adela's request, he extends his invitation to Dr. Aziz. At Fielding's tea party, everyone has a good time conversing about India, and Fielding and Aziz even become great friends. Aziz buoyantly promises to take Mrs. Moore and Adela to see the Marabar Caves, a distant cave complex that everyone talks about but no one seems to actually visit. Aziz's Marabar invitation was one of those casual promises that people often make and never intend to keep. Ronny Heaslop arrives and rudely breaks up the party. Aziz mistakenly believes that the women are really offended that he has not followed through on his promise and arranges the outing at great expense to himself. Fielding and Godbole were supposed to accompany the little expedition, but they miss the train. Aziz and the women begin to explore the caves. In the first cave, however, Mrs. Moore is overcome with claustrophobia, for the cave is dark and Aziz's retinue has followed her in. The press of people nearly smothers her. But worse than the claustrophobia is the echo. No matter what sound one makes, the echo is always "Boum." Disturbed by the echo, Mrs. Moore declines to continue exploring. So Adela and Aziz, accompanied by a single guide, a local man, climb on up the hill to the next cluster of caves. As Aziz helps Adela up the hill, she innocently asks him whether he has more than one wife. Disconcerted by the bluntness of the remark, he ducks into a cave to compose himself. When he comes out, he finds the guide sitting alone outside the caves. The guide says Adela has gone into one of the caves by herself. Aziz looks for her in vain. Deciding she is lost, he angrily punches the guide, who runs away. Aziz looks around again and discovers Adela's field-glasses (similar to binoculars) lying broken on the ground. He puts them in his pocket. Then Aziz looks down the hill and sees Adela speaking to another young Englishwoman, Miss Derek, who has arrived with Fielding in a car. Aziz runs down the hill and greets Fielding effusively, but Miss Derek and Adela have already driven off without a word of explanation. Fielding, Mrs. Moore, and Aziz return to Chandrapore on the train. Then the blow falls. At the train station, Dr. Aziz is arrested and charged with sexually assaulting Adela in a cave. She reports the alleged incident to the British authorities. The run-up to Aziz's trial for attempted sexual assault releases the racial tensions between the British and the Indians. Adela accuses Aziz only of trying to touch her. She says that he followed her into the cave and tried to grab her, and that she fended him off by swinging her field glasses at him. She remembers him grabbing the glasses and the strap breaking, which allowed her to get away. The only actual evidence the British have is the field glasses in the possession of Dr. Aziz. Despite this, the British colonists firmly believe that Aziz is guilty; at the back of all their minds is the conviction that all darker peoples lust after white women. They are stunned when Fielding proclaims his belief in Aziz's innocence. Fielding is ostracized and condemned as a blood-traitor. But the Indians, who consider the assault allegation a fraud aimed at ruining their community's reputation, welcome him. During the weeks before the trial, Mrs. Moore is unexpectedly apathetic and irritable. Her experience in the cave seems to have ruined her faith in humanity. Although she curtly professes her belief in Aziz's innocence, she does nothing to help him. Ronny, alarmed by his mother's assertion that Aziz is innocent, decides to arrange for her return by ship to England before she can testify to this effect at the trial. Mrs. Moore dies during the voyage. Her absence from India becomes a major issue at the trial, where Aziz's legal defenders assert that her testimony alone, had it been available, would have proven the accused's innocence. After an initial period of fever and weeping, Adela becomes confused as to Aziz's guilt. At the trial, she is asked point-blank whether Aziz sexually assaulted her. She asks for a moment to think before replying. She has a vision of the cave in that moment, and it turns out that Adela had, while in the cave, received a shock similar to Mrs. Moore's. The echo had disconcerted her so much that she temporarily became unhinged. She ran around the cave, fled down the hill, and finally sped off with Miss Derek. At the time, Adela mistakenly interpreted her shock as an assault by Aziz, who personifies the India that has stripped her of her psychological innocence, but he was never there. She admits that she was mistaken. The case is dismissed. (Note that in the 1913 draft of the novel EM Forster originally had Aziz guilty of the assault and found guilty in the court, but later changed this in the 1924 draft to create a more ambiguous ending). All the English are shocked and infuriated by what they view as Adela's betrayal of the white race. Ronny Heaslop breaks off their engagement. Adela stays at Fielding's house until her passage on a boat to England is arranged. After explaining to Fielding that the echo was the cause of the whole business, she departs India, never to return. Although he is free and vindicated, Aziz is angry and bitter that his friend, Fielding, would befriend Adela after she nearly ruined his life. Believing it to be the gentlemanly thing to do, Fielding convinces Aziz not to seek monetary redress from her. The two men's friendship suffers in consequence, and Fielding soon departs for England. Aziz believes that he is leaving to marry Adela for her money. Bitter at his friend's perceived betrayal, he vows never again to befriend a white person. Aziz moves to the Hindu-ruled state of Mau and begins a new life. Two years later, Fielding returns to India and to Aziz. His wife is Stella, Mrs. Moore's daughter from a second marriage. Aziz, now the Raja's chief physician, at first persists in his anger against his old friend. But in time, he comes to respect and love Fielding again. However, he does not give up his dream of a free and united India. In the novel's last sentences, he explains that he and Fielding cannot be friends, at least not until India is free of the British Raj. Even the earth and the sky seem to say, "Not yet."
pred: Chandrapore is described in this chapter as having gardens and a forest. The inhabitants of the forest, which are covered with mud, rise out of their stifling temples. They do not seem to be sad, but rather intrigued by the fact that they are surrounded by trees and flowers. At one point, however , Aziz loses his bicycle and falls on the veranda. He apologizes profusely for his late arrival and asks to see his wife. She tells him that she has had a conversation with a doctor who asked her to look after his wounded leg. Afterward, he goes off to visit his family at the Sarajevo Mosque. While there, he encounters an old Indian woman whom he does not recognize; she tries to get him to tell her about the incident at the Masjid. Later, when he returns home, he learns that the local authorities have decided to issue an invitation to several Indian women from the Turton household so that they may meet with them during the week. The Bridge Party is a disappointment. The narrator notes that the Indians do not show up for the bridge party, despite the fact that many of them have come from India. They speak of Cousin Kate, which has been praised by the local newspaper, but an unsophisticated edition of the paper reports that Miss Darcys and Mrs. Barlow are unable to attend due to their lack of English language proficiency. Meanwhile, Fielding tries to appeal to his Indian compatriots about how they should behave with respect in India. He tells them that he will be coming to tea on Thursday. When Fielding returns home, he discovers that he has forgotten to bring his wife's portrait to tea; this makes him even more unhappy. Fielding introduces himself to a group of Indian ladies who are coming for tea. They all agree that they will be having a good time, but when Aziz mentions India, Fielding is offended because he has never been to India before. He then tells them about his practice in India and how he hopes to one day become a doctor there. After the women leave, Rodolpho asks if they would like to go see him in the "Marabar caves" with some Englishmen. When Adela says she doesn't want to visit India at all though, he responds by saying that she can come too. The next morning, after much arguing over which direction to travel, they run into an Indian man whom they have not yet spoken to. This upsets Ronny so much that he falls asleep. Later, on their way home from the meeting, MissQuested suggests to her mother that they call it quits. She wants to get out of this situation as quickly as possible. The next day, Fielding asks about the happenings at the roadside inn. The narrator tells us that he and his grandson are playing a game called "Patience" in which they try to convince each other of the supernatural powers of heaven and earth. Unfortunately, this game is not going very well. After some time has passed, the group decides to go back to their hotel for another round of matrimonial meetings. This time, however, there is no one there to listen to them; instead, they rely on fielding as their mediator. They decide to set up a mock-Tea Party with Aziz's family so that she will be able to keep track of her husband while he is away. As soon as they leave the teacup, people start talking about Cholera and its effects on the health of the Indian population. It becomes clear that these conversations have been misinterpreted by the English authorities as an attempt to improve relations between India and the West. The next morning, the travelers board the train for Sharm el-Sheikh, who is to serve as Major-Domo. After a few days of travel, they arrive in Sharm El-Weikh, accompanied by his friends and their hired Indian servant, Mohammed al-Farooq. They all agree that this trip will be interesting, although Adela finds it hard to get along with her fellow travelers because she has been traveling without them for two months. She also realizes that she does not have enough time to devote to any one person during the entire journey; instead, she must devote herself entirely to making others happy. Meanwhile, on the train ride back to India, Arabella discovers that she has run away from her hyena's burial place. The only thing she can do is talk to her family about her feelings for them. Fielding discovers that Aziz has been invited to the picnic by Fielding's mistress, Miss Derek; he had planned to take her back to his Indian friends. The excursion is over when Fielding finds out that she has gone missing. He apologizes for being late, and explains that there was no such thing as an impromptu picnic because Aziz did not want to make it up to MissQuested. After Fielding leaves, Major Munro arrives with the news of Aziz' arrest. He asks Fielding to help him find a way to free Aziz without having to force him into any trouble. As Fielding departs, Turton informs him that they are going to have to issue bail for Aziz in order to clear his name. When fielding tries to intervene, Munro tells Fielding that if Aziz does not get bail then he will be arrested himself. This makes Fielding even more determined to go after Aziz personally. Fielding tries to defend himself, but is attacked by the Collector. He tells them that Aziz has paid a prostitute to suffice his mother before she could get out. The collector then accuses him of bribing and threatens to release him if he does not do so. After this incident, they move on to their new allies in the district. They all feel sorry for Adela because she seems to have no real interest in anything other than her own past. She begins to cry more frequently when she thinks about the fact that she will soon be dead. Meanwhile, Major Oakeshott makes an attempt to convince her that perhaps she should leave India as quickly as possible since she cannot stand up for herself anymore. The trial begins. The superintendent of police, the district attorney, and several other officials testify against Aziz in front of a packed courtroom. He makes no moral appeal to the audience, but he does speak eloquently about the importance of an Indian judge presiding over a criminal case. When Adela appears on the witness stand, she tells the story of how she came to be near Aziz at the bridge party. She says that she has come to see him because she is tired from tea with him. At this point Fielding comes up with a solution for her: she should return to their place of residence so they can discuss the matter further. But when she arrives, she finds out that Mr. Gardiner has been taken away by his own son who was supposed to take care of her. Mrs. Moorhouse refuses to allow her to attend the court hearing; she wants to go home instead. Fielding and the other Englishmen are saddened by the death of their witness, Adela Moore. Hamidullah has news for them as well: her mother is dead. She died in a shipwreck during the voyage to India. The narrator notes that Fielding feels guilty about having let Adela go; he does not want his friend to go through with such an emotional rollercoaster. He also realizes that they do not have much in common apart from each other. They become closer because of religious differences between themselves and the Indian community. Their relationship develops further when Fielding tries to convince Aziz to allow Adela to attend Government College so that she will not be forced back into England. Meanwhile, Arabella continues to make fun of Fielding's Indian friends, who treat him cruelly even though he tried to help her out at the trial. In Chapter XXIX, it turns out that both men are deeply affected by the loss of their mentor, Professor Godbole. When Fielding returns home, he discovers that Aziz has been blackmailing Adela while she was away on a trip to Europe. This causes tension between the two men. Fielding attends the masjid, but when he returns home, he finds that Aziz and Fielding have been misunderstanding one another. He tells Aziz that he is leaving for England to pursue a career as a doctor. The next day, Fielding writes Aziz a letter in which he accuses Aziz of being a snotty old man who does not like women. Afterward, he takes his children with him on a trip to Europe. On the way, he stops by Mau, where he meets up with Fielding again. They are introduced to each other through their mutual respect and admiration of each other; they also learn from each other about the relationship between the two men. As soon as Fielding leaves, an all-Indian religious procession begins. It ends at sunset. At this point, it has begun to rain. Meanwhile, fielding receives a mysterious letter from Fielding saying that he will be returning to India soon. advertisement

title: The Plague
target: The text of The Plague is divided into five parts. In the town of Oran, thousands of rats, initially unnoticed by the populace, begin to die in the streets. A hysteria develops soon afterward, causing the local newspapers to report the incident. Authorities responding to public pressure order the collection and cremation of the rats, unaware that the collection itself was the catalyst for the spread of the bubonic plague. The main character, Dr. Bernard Rieux, lives comfortably in an apartment building when strangely the building's concierge, M. Michel, a confidante, dies from a fever. Dr. Rieux consults his colleague, Castel, about the illness until they come to the conclusion that a plague is sweeping the town. They both approach fellow doctors and town authorities about their theory, but are eventually dismissed on the basis of one death. However, as more and more deaths quickly ensue, it becomes apparent that there is an epidemic. Authorities, including the Prefect, M. Othon, are slow to accept that the situation is serious and quibble over the appropriate action to take. Official notices enacting control measures are posted, but the language used is optimistic and downplays the seriousness of the situation. A "special ward" is opened at the hospital, but its 80 beds are filled within three days. As the death toll begins to rise, more desperate measures are taken. Homes are quarantined; corpses and burials are strictly supervised. A supply of plague serum finally arrives, but there is only enough to treat existing cases and the country's emergency reserves are depleted. When the daily number of deaths jumps to 30, the town is sealed and an outbreak of plague is officially declared. The town is sealed off. The town gates are shut, rail travel is prohibited, and all mail service is suspended. The use of telephone lines is restricted only to "urgent" calls, leaving short telegrams as the only means of communicating with friends or family outside the town. The separation affects daily activity and depresses the spirit of the townspeople, who begin to feel isolated and introverted, and the plague begins to affect various characters. One character, Raymond Rambert, devises a plan to escape the city to join his lover in Paris after city officials refuse his request to leave. He befriends some criminals so that they may smuggle him out of the city. Another character, Father Paneloux, uses the plague as an opportunity to advance his stature in the town by suggesting that the plague was an act of God punishing the citizens' sinful nature. His diatribe falls on the ears of many citizens of the town, who turned to religion in droves but would not have done so under normal circumstances. Cottard, a criminal remorseful enough to attempt suicide yet fearful of being arrested, becomes wealthy as a major smuggler. Meanwhile, Dr. Rieux, a vacationer Jean Tarrou, and a civil servant Joseph Grand exhaustively treat patients in their homes and in the hospital. Rambert informs Tarrou of his escape plan, but when Tarrou tells him that others in the city, including Dr. Rieux, also have loved ones outside the city whom they are not allowed to see, Rambert becomes sympathetic and changes his mind. He then decides to join Tarrou and Dr. Rieux to help fight the epidemic. In mid-August, the situation continues to worsen. People try to escape the town, but some are shot by armed sentries. Violence and looting break out on a small scale, and the authorities respond by declaring martial law and imposing a curfew. Funerals are conducted with more and more speed, no ceremony, and little concern for the feelings of the families of the deceased. The inhabitants passively endure their increasing feelings of exile and separation; despondent, they waste away emotionally as well as physically. In September and October, the town remains at the mercy of the plague. Rieux hears from the sanatorium that his wife's condition is worsening. He also hardens his heart regarding the plague victims so that he can continue to do his work. Cottard, on the other hand, seems to flourish during the plague, because it gives him a sense of being connected to others, since everybody faces the same danger. Cottard and Tarrou attend a performance of Gluck's opera Orpheus and Eurydice, but the actor portraying Orpheus collapses with plague symptoms during the performance. Rambert finally has a chance to escape, but he decides to stay, saying that he would feel ashamed of himself if he left. Towards the end of October, Castel's new anti-plague serum is tried for the first time, but it cannot save the life of Othon's young son, who suffers greatly, as Paneloux, Rieux, and Tarrou look on in horror. Paneloux, who has joined the group of volunteers fighting the plague, gives a second sermon. He addresses the problem of an innocent child's suffering and says it is a test of a Christian's faith, since it requires him either to deny everything or believe everything. He urges the congregation not to give up the struggle but to do everything possible to fight the plague. A few days after the sermon, Paneloux is taken ill. His symptoms do not conform to those of the plague, but the disease still proves fatal. Tarrou and Rambert visit one of the isolation camps, where they meet Othon. When Othon's period of quarantine ends, he elects to stay in the camp as a volunteer because this will make him feel less separated from his dead son. Tarrou tells Rieux the story of his life, and the two men go swimming together in the sea. Grand catches the plague and instructs Rieux to burn all his papers. But Grand makes an unexpected recovery, and deaths from the plague start to decline. By late January, the plague is in full retreat, and the townspeople begin to celebrate the imminent opening of the town gates. Othon, however, does not escape death from the disease. Cottard is distressed by the ending of the epidemic, from which he has profited by shady dealings. Two government employees approach him, and he flees. Despite the epidemic's ending, Tarrou contracts the plague and dies after an heroic struggle. Rieux's wife also dies. In February, the town gates open and people are reunited with their loved ones from other cities. Rambert is reunited with his wife. Rieux reveals that he is the narrator of the chronicle and that he tried to present an objective view of the events. Cottard goes mad and shoots at people from his home. He is arrested. Grand begins working on his sentence again. Rieux reflects on the epidemic and reaches the conclusion that there is more to admire than to despise in humans.
pred: "The Plague" is the first volume of a satirical e-book, and it was published in August of that year by Analog Science Fiction. The text is an extended edition of "Analog Science Fact/Fiction February 1961" with additional information added by Teddy Keller. In this book, all the major players in the military are involved in creating a public health crisis for the American people. They must respond immediately to any outbreaks of disease or illness caused by a non-com; they must contact local authorities, doctors, nurses, and other emergency personnel who will be on the front lines during the crisis. A surgeon general announces that he has placed two officers on special duty--the brigadier general and the lieutenant colonel--to investigate the situation. He informs them that if they fail to do so, their duties will be suspended until they find a suitable replacement. Meanwhile, the narrator notes that there have been no official releases from the hospital regarding the outbreak of the plague due to the fact that none of the medical personnel were able to attend the crisis meeting. This makes the narrator wonder about the future of the war.

title: Venus in Furs
target: The framing story concerns a man who dreams of speaking to Venus about love while she wears furs. The unnamed narrator tells his dreams to a friend, Severin, who tells him how to break him of his fascination with cruel women by reading a manuscript, Memoirs of a Suprasensual Man. This manuscript tells of a man, Severin von Kusiemski, who is so infatuated with a woman, Wanda von Dunajew, that he asks to be her slave, and encourages her to treat him in progressively more degrading ways. At first Wanda does not understand or accede to the request, but after humouring Severin a bit she finds the advantages of the method to be interesting and enthusiastically embraces the idea, although at the same time she disdains Severin for allowing her to do so. Severin describes his feelings during these experiences as suprasensuality. Severin and Wanda travel to Florence. Along the way, Severin takes the generic Russian servant's name of "Gregor" and the role of Wanda's servant. In Florence, Wanda treats him brutally as a servant, and recruits a trio of African women to dominate him. The relationship arrives at a crisis when Wanda herself meets a man to whom she would like to submit, a Byronic hero known as Alexis Papadopolis. At the end of the book, Severin, humiliated by Wanda's new lover, loses the desire to submit. He says of Wanda:
pred: This chapter introduces the reader to Ritter. Ritter is a Francophobe who has lived in Galicia since 1836, and he died in 1895 at the age of sixty-five. He was an Austrian Jew originally from Galicia but moved to Paris in 1855. His work on psycho-sensual literature dates back more than a century. The main focus of his works is Venus in Furst, which focuses on romantic love between a woman and a man. In this chapter, Ritter explains how he came to be attracted to Wanda after meeting her as a young girl with a long hair and a curving nose. When she asks him why he loves her, he tells her that it is because they are lovers. She responds by saying that men can only have so much pleasure if they allow themselves to be dominated by women. This makes Ritter even more determined to find a way to win her. Wanda convinces Severin that they should live as if they were married. She tells him that he will become her husband and she will become Severin's wife. For the past ten days, Severino has been with Wanda every day except during the night. At one point in the course of their conversation, she asks Severin whether he would like to possess her or not. He replies that he does not want to because he loves her so much. After a while, though, his love for her diminishes. When she leaves, he becomes even more entranced by her beauty and sensuality; this arouses his interest in her. They spend many happy hours together despite the fact that she is away from home. One day, she sends him a note saying that she wants him to come visit her at least once a month. A few weeks later, she invites him to join her when she lives with another woman. The next day, he goes to see her. While there, he sees blood trickling from her eyes. A Russian prince makes his first visit to the Tazzaevs on Wanda's behalf. He immediately becomes attracted to her, but when she tells him that she wants to know more about him, he refuses to listen or even allow her to speak with him. After a few days of this behavior, she finally agrees to give up her relationship with Ganymede and become his mistress. The next day, they board a train bound for Florence. They arrive in Florence just before midnight. During their honeymoon, both women are forced to sleep in uncomfortable sleeping cubicles. For the next month, they go house hunting together. At one point, they meet Wanda at her apartment. She instructs them to take her to her bedroom where she will be confined until she can find a place to live again. As long as she is there, everything goes according to plan. Wanda wakes up Severin and tells him that she wants him to sleep in her house. She also instructs him to go and dress in Carpathia, which reminds him of how beautiful Wanda used to be when they were lovers. He falls asleep listening to Wanda speak to him about his feelings for her. The next morning, the maid notices that Wanda has brought along a painter whom she is going to meet later that day at the theater. This makes her even more determined to get rid of him because she knows he will eventually kill her. That night, she gives birth to a beautiful lioness named Wanda herself. A young man named Gregor arrives on his way to see Wanda while she is taking care of another client. Afterward, she takes him by the hand and leads him into the bedroom where he finds Wanda sitting with a book close to her heart. They continue to talk until the end of the conversation. advertisement

title: The Jungle
target: The main character in the book is a Lithuanian man called Jurgis Rudkus, an immigrant to the United States trying to make ends meet. The book begins describing the wedding feast beginning at four o'clock after the marriage in Chicago of Jurgis to a fifteen year old Lithuanian girl named Ona Lukoszaite whom he had known from his Lithuanian days. The second chapter goes back to when Jurgis and Ona were in Lithuania before they married and Jurgis's courtship of her, the death of her father, and their decision to start dating and eventually immigrate to the United States along with her stepmother Teta Elzbieta, and their extended family after hearing how their relative Jokubas Szedvilas is making money there. In the second and third chapters Jurgis and Ona settle in Chicago's infamous Packingtown district, where from the start, Jurgis takes a job at Brown's slaughterhouse. (Brown was a pseudonym for Armour and Company.) Jurgis believes when he immigrates to the United States that it will be a land of more freedom, but soon his employer's treatment of him disappoints him. Alas, they have to make compromises and concessions to survive. Due partly to illiteracy in English, they quickly make a series of bad decisions that cause them to go deep into debt and fall prey to con men. The most devastating decision comes when, in hopes of owning their own home, the family falls victim to a predatory lending scheme that exhausts all their remaining savings on the down-payment for a sub-standard slum house that (by design) they cannot possibly afford. The family is evicted and their money taken, leaving them truly devastated. The family had formerly envisioned that Jurgis alone would be able to support them in the United States, but one by one, all of them—the women, the young children, and Jurgis' sick father—have to find jobs in order to contribute to the meager family income. As the novel progresses, the jobs and means the family uses to stay alive slowly and inevitably lead to their physical and moral decay. A series of unfortunate events—accidents at work, along with a number of deaths in the family that under normal circumstances could have been prevented—leads the family further toward catastrophe. One injury results in Jurgis being fired; he later takes a job at Durham's fertilizer plant. (Durham was a pseudonym for Swift and Company.) The family's tragedies cumulate when Ona confesses to Jurgis, who is suspicious of her frequent absences from home, that her boss, Phil Connor, had raped her, and made her job dependent on her giving him sexual favors. In revenge, Jurgis later attacks Connor, leading to his arrest and imprisonment by the corrupt judge Pat Callahan, who sides with Connor against Jurgis. After his stint in jail, Jurgis returns home, only to find out that his family has been evicted. He finds his family at a relative's house; Jurgis also discovers Ona in labor with her second child. Ona dies in childbirth from blood loss at the age of eighteen. Jurgis lacked money to pay for a doctor; so Ona has to rely on the greedy and incompetent Madame Haupt, whose carelessness leads to Ona's death. Soon after their first child drowns in the muddy street, causing Jurgis to flee the city in utter despair and turn to drinking. At first the mere presence of fresh air is balm to his soul, but his brief sojourn as a hobo in rural United States shows him that there is really no escape—even farmers turn their workers away when the harvest is finished. Jurgis returns to Chicago and holds down a succession of jobs outside the meat packing industry—digging tunnels, as a political hack, and as a con-man—but injuries on the job, his past and his innate sense of personal integrity continue to haunt him, and he drifts without direction. One night, while looking for a warm and dry refuge, he wanders into a lecture being given by a charismatic Socialist orator, and finds a sense of community and purpose. Socialism and strong labor unions are the answer to the evils that he, his family and their fellow sufferers have had to endure. A fellow socialist employs him, and he resumes his support of his wife's family, although some of them are damaged beyond repair. The book ends with another socialist rally, which comes on the heels of several recent political victories. The speaker encourages his comrades to keep fighting for victories, chanting "Chicago will be ours!"
pred: The wedding feast takes place in the back of a converted saloon. The celebration begins and ends at four o'clock, when Ona Lydias is introduced. Shepherds her niece through the crowded hallways and into the banquet hall where she waits with her cousin for the entire family to enjoy the food and drink. After the meal, guests begin arriving from all over the city. Many of them are young men who work as beef-bboners; others are old people who have lost their jobs due to alcohol poisoning. At one point during the party, Jugis tells Ona that he will make more money by working harder. In the summer of 1855, Jonas Szedlago leaves Vilnius to go live in America with his friend Marija and their two children. On the way, they meet a policeman who tries to arrest them for trespassing on railroad tracks. They learn that Chicago is where they will stay for the time being. The next day, they board a train headed for New York City. Once there, they find themselves surrounded by "shabby little buildings" full of dirty, rotten goods. In an attempt to escape, Jonas runs away from the police and hides himself behind a tree. When he comes back, he tells everyone that he has found a job as a meat packing agent. He also tells everyone else that it is not too expensive because all the packing companies sell their wares directly to the American marketplaces. During this vacation period, Jonas travels to see the sights firsthand. While at the packing plant, Jonas sees a giant iron wheel driving a large portion of beef through the factory floor. It is then lowered into a chilling room so that the animals won't get sick during the meal. Jonas watches the entire process unfold before him. The family purchases a house from an agent who tells them they can buy it for as little as $15.00 a month and pay no rent at all. They are shocked to learn that they will be forced to rent the house out in order to make ends meet. The agents advise them to wait until they have more time before making their purchase, which takes place between Thursday and Sunday evening. After much debate, they finally agree to go through with the purchase once again. This time, though, the real estate agent warns them that there may be some problems with the lease on the house if they do not pay the mortgage. Onas is particularly upset when he learns that his stepmother has been injured during the process of picking up the pieces of furniture used in the houses. He also learns that Antanas Rudeius serves as one of those "grumblers," or old witches. The chapter opens with a description of the Packingtoy house. According to the narrator, it is 15 years old and has nothing new on it except the paint that needs to be replaced every two years or so. The story goes something like this: When the family first bought the place, they expected to lose their house because no one would pay for it. However, after four failed attempts, they are finally able to raise the money enough to pay off the mortgage. They now have seven dollars left over from the sale of the previous house. This puts them over the $1,000 mark. Meanwhile, Stanislavskiene continues to work as a dishwasher at Brown's grocery store. He also works as a violinist in a nearby saloon. During the winter, he begins to bleed profusely from frostbite caused by salt peter, a chemical used to kill insects. After several months of constant suffering, his blood pressure drops dangerously low. In order to keep him from getting frostbite, Jugis must go to various saloons and buy alcohol. The union movement begins to take hold of the American working class. They begin to organize meetings in order to get their members to join, and by organizing these meetings, they can make a real impact on the packer community. The union movement also creates an opportunity for immigrants to gain access to the U.S. political system, which allows them to bypass the shackling industry and instead become part-time laborers who work as night watchmen at local packing plants. In this way, immigrant workers are not only protected from disease but also able to communicate effectively with one another without fear of retribution. Meanwhile, Jimis learns that America does not just have a government; rather, it has a system based on graft and corruption. During the spring and summer months, the family is forced to live off the tens of thousands of dollars spent each year on food and medicine. On top of all this, there are still plenty of jobs available for immigrants because no one really knows what they're getting into yet. In the summer of 1855, Packedtown is in full swing again. The packers take on more new workers and are forced to cut back on wages. One day Marija happens upon a line of working women waiting for a bank to open. She takes advantage of this opportunity to get money from them by running into a group of them who want to withdraw their deposits at the bank. They do not have much money, so they set up a savings account. Meanwhile, Jonas has lost his job as a lard-mending machine operator due to a broken ankle. During these difficult times, Onas suffers an accident that causes him to lose both his left hand and right leg. He also suffers frostbite in his foot. In April, Jonas disappears. Jugis attempts to find work but is refused a job because he is too weak to walk or sit still long enough to rest. A few weeks later, Stanislavas' leg gets seriously injured during a snowstorm. It turns out that the injury was caused by a faulty electric current. In the summer of the following year, laborers at the fertilizer plant become increasingly desperate for work. The family begins to prepare for the arrival of their children, who will attend school in order to earn a living. However, due to the difficulty of shoveling fertilizer from the mill into carts full of people waiting to buy it, many young men are forced to work as sous-chefs or waitresses on the factory floor. Many of these jobs include picking up discarded meat and preparing it for later consumption. During this time period, Ona is pregnant with her first child. She suffers from severe headaches and nervousness; she also suffers from periods of convulsion that lead her to cry out in pain. When Ona finally comes home, she tells Jurgys that she has had an accident during the course of the nightmarish pregnancy. He believes her but does not believe her until he hears her story. The next morning, after being locked up for the past two months, Darnay makes his way back to Chicago. He arrives at the police station and is told that he has a warrant out for assault on him. When he leaves the station, he finds Connor waiting for him outside in the loading yard. Connor tells Jurgys that they will lose their house if Connor doesn't take care of them soon enough. After Connor leaves, Ona's father-in-law comes to see her and says that Connor tried to seduce Ona while she was pregnant. The father then calls Forster into testimony about how Connor treated Ona during an extended period of time when Ona wasn't around. Then one day, StanislOVas shows up at the jail looking very disheveled. It turns out that this man is Jack Donnithorne, another convicted felon who had served time in prison for robbing a shipping company. In other words, it looks like there is a fire going on in the prison. The narrator describes the aftermath of the earthquake and its effects on the family. He notes that Ona's death has been a turning point in her life, as she was forced to give birth to an illegitimate child. The narrator also paints a vivid picture of how people react when they hear or see their loved ones crying out in front of them. When Marija comes to pick up some food from the kitchen counter, she finds Ona dead. She cries out again for help, but is met only with derision by the men at the fertilizer plant who tell her it is too late. They take her body back to the factory and place her in a locked garret so that she can have time to think before taking care of her sick husband. Meanwhile, Elzieta continues to live off the money given to her by her former lover Jonas. Finally, after months of searching for work, he finally gets a job selling papers in a fertilizer plant. But there are no jobs for him because his wages are way too high. In order to make ends meet, Elizieta sends Jurgys to look for work downtown. After a few months, the Tramp is offered a job at the local steelworks. He works there for three weeks and earns a good deal of money by working alongside other laborers. After several more failed attempts, he finally gets a job as a helper in a neighboring mill. The work is very demanding and repetitive, with many hours spent on day-to-day grinds and grinding machines. During this time period, Elzieta sends Antanas to live with her family in a lodging house. When Antanas awakens one morning, he finds that his father has drowned in the stock market. Reluctant to leave his family behind, Jaquenetta drives him home. The Underground Man In Chicago One Saturday night, after a rainstorm, Jim finds shelter from the elements in a dilapidated house near a workingman's home. The owner of the home informs Jim that his wife and youngest child have been sleeping outdoors while he takes a bath in a well-stocked laundry room. After Jim falls asleep, he wakes up to find Freddie Jones, who tells him that he is going to be spending Christmas with his fiancee. He also learns that Freddie has broken his arm doing some heavy lifting on the railroad tracks. When Freddie leaves for the holiday season, they all meet again at a crowded bus stop. Freddie asks Jurgys if he can borrow money so that he can buy food for himself when he needs it. They go off to a large hall full of high-quality banquet halls filled with gambling tables, beer gardens, and other luxuries. Finally, they arrive at a small apartment where Freddie gives Jurgius a $100 bill. Failing to pay, Freddie drinks the entire contents down into his mouth. Jurgis meets Jack Duanes, who tells him all about his family and the illegal activities of the gambling industry in Chicago. He also explains to Duane how he got blacklisted for soliciting a prostitute while working as a laborer at a pawnshop. Jugis is then offered a job as a member of the local Republican Party, but refuses to accept it until Duane convinces him to do so. When Duane finally agrees to go along with this plan, Jurgeris takes advantage of the opportunity presented to him by Scully to get some money from the gambling business. In order to make ends meet, however--and perhaps more importantly, to keep himself safe during an election year when no one seems to care that much about the outcome of the election--he hires Duane's old pal, Bush Harper, who helps him find a job running a gambling establishment. During the election season, Jim becomes embroiled in a prostitution scandal, which results in ten dollars in fines and a $10,000 fine. The strike continues for several more weeks. Finally, in June, the union demands a vote on whether or not to hold off the strike until the strike is over. The packers refuse to pay the workers' wages and instead force them to work as scabbing laborers. On his first day back at work, Jim Scully asks him why he doesn't just stick with his job. Scully explains that it's because they need "good men" who can stand by their side. After two hours of this conversation, Jugis gives up his job and goes outside to get some beer. He tells Scully that he has come to Chicago to try to find a job so he can help out Mike Scully. Scully agrees to go along with the plan. Soon enough, Jorgis finds himself in the middle of a political rally. It turns out that there is a strike going on all around the country between five and six weeks when the voters will elect a President. This puts Jurgi in a unique position to make an impact on the lives of countless black people throughout the country. In order to counteract this effect, Jergis hires a prostitute named Alena from a nearby saloon. Alena reveals herself as Jessica Connor, one of Mulder Scully's top lieutenants. She says that she is pregnant and wants to be married. When her name is called, Harper grants her permission to marry Jessica. They are married shortly thereafter. After the shooting, Jugis goes to visit Marija and finds her in a dilapidated brownstone home. She tells him that she lives with Stanislas Tetaislovskas, Stanislaus' brother-in-law, and another relative of hers. He is then taken to a small cell where he meets Marija's cousin, Alexandra Jerenski. During their conversation, they discuss the horrors of life in Leningrad. They both agree that there must be some kind of end to this cycle of oppression. The narrator concludes by stating that these are the very conditions for which slavery has been sown. In order to counterbalance his argument, Zdravko suggests that all women should be allowed to work as maids instead of prostitutes. This seems like a good idea at the time; however, it does not seem to have any effect on Marija or her family during this chapter. At last, Dr. Barlow announces that Madame Pernelle has arranged for Marija to take over the position of supervising nursemaid. Jurenski immediately realizes that such an end will not be in sight. The Socialist Party of America rallies its members in order to organize and support the Socialist Party. The meeting ends with a speech by Ostrinkins, a Polish orator who has been traveling throughout the U.S. since the Civil War. After the speech, an adoring crowd gathers at the convention floor for a night of drinking and socializing. Comrade Josephus Ostrinkski, a former Socialist Party official, meets Jurgius and introduces him to his new employer, Comrade Tommy Hinds . Over the course of the next few weeks, Jim becomes increasingly disillusioned with socialism. He begins to attend Socialist meetings and become involved in socialist politics. The editor of an Eastern magazine asks Adams and Maynard to start a discussion about "pure food" in which they will discuss religion. Jugis is nervous because he has never spoken to women before. He does not understand the concept of religion, so he assumes that they are Socialists or communists. The editor disagrees with this interpretation, claiming that there must be some kind of class distinction between people who have money and those who don't. Lucas argues that religion is the best defense against all forms of oppression, pointing out that if a woman could dictate terms for herself and her family, then she would be free to do whatever she wants with her life. This debate continues into the election of the next year. In order to determine whether socialism will actually work, the narrator explains that it will certainly not. advertisement

title: The Magician
target: The story takes place in Ossining, New York. Ed Japhet is sixteen years old, and he is a bright, articulate boy. His father Terence teaches at his school. Ed's hobby is performing magic tricks, hence he is the "magician" of the title. One evening, Ed performs in front of the school on prom night, and aggravates school hoodlum Urek. Urek and his gang wait for Ed that night as he is about to go home with his dad and girlfriend. Urek attacks Ed and nearly kills him. Urek is eventually arrested on a charge of serious assault. At first this looks like a straightforward case. But Urek's dad happens to have a lawyer named Thomassy, who has made it his life's work to defend the low-lifes and the criminals of the area - and to get them off the hook. When Thomassy started his promising career as a lawyer he joined a firm with WASP surnames deliberately. They took him on and he became their most brilliant lawyer. However, the senior partner told him that as an Armenian he would never get promoted, at least while he was alive. Thomassy, stung, left and decided to follow a controversial path defending the most undesirable characters in society. He sends a birthday card every year to the old senior partner, as if to say, "You still alive?" As the story unfolds, the reader becomes uncomfortably aware of how an event can be interpreted by the law. It seems as though Ed has the advantage, he is talented, with a nice family and girlfriend, horribly attacked and nearly killed by a brute. But Thomassy manages to play the attack down: he discredits witnesses, intimidates others, and portrays Urek as acting only in self defense. Now the reader is unsure who the actual "magician" of the title really is. Also involved is German Jewish Psychiatrist Koch, who has taken an interest in the case. His involvement gives the reader an opportunity to see Urek in more depth, as previously he is portrayed as a mindless, violent and inarticulate monster. Nothing can excuse what he has done, but Koch offers more insight as to why he did it. The book ends on a violent note. Urek walks free from the assault charge and proceeds to attack Ed again, this time by hiding in Terence's car and leaping out at Ed. Ed, newly trained in Karate, can now defend himself against the thuggish Urek, with devastating results. Terence Japhet knows exactly whom to call. The book is written in the third person narrative style, but interspersed at intervals throughout the story are "comments" provided by the key characters. They are written in the style of statements, but the reader never knows to whom they are directed.
pred: In this chapter, Arthur begins his story. He is a thirty-year-old Englishman who has just passed medical school and is now practicing medicine in London. After passing the examinations required for him to practice medicine, he decides to abandon doctors and earn his living writing novels. He travels to Spain and spends a year there before returning to England as a professional writer. His first novel is published in 1897; his second is a play called A Man of Honor that fails to make much of a stir. In order to escape his banishment, Arthur visits Paris with Dr. Porhoizt, an art student at St. Luke's Hospital. They spend time together while Arthur works on his latest novel. Arthur asks about Margaret, whom he sees sitting across from him. She tells him that she loves him very much. Arthur then goes to see Madame Rouge , her mistress. The two sit down to eat tea together. Arthur admires Madame Ragueneau, whose beauty reminds him of Caius de Guiche . Susie tries to get Arthur to talk to Margaret about how beautiful she is. Arthur also talks about Mr. O'Brien, one of Arthur's painters. Arthur says that if Margaret ever marries him, they will have to marry separately. Haddo shows up at the inn. He pretends to be a professional magician, but when he sees Susie and Margaret looking at him suspiciously, he tells them that he is from Eastern Europe. They all go in search of clues as to his origins and where he came from. The men are introduced to Arthur, who introduces them to Dr Poyser, Monsieur Borro, Arthur's old friend, and Sir Ivanhoe. Then it is time for the English party to head off to the Paris fair. There, they find out that there is a traveling circus going on around the city. And guess what? Haddoes latest addition to the show is a rattlesnake-like creature called Zohar . It is described as "a kind of grotesque creature" , which means it resembles snakes or porcine  only slightly more sinister. In fact, its name comes from Casanova, the famous Egyptian antiquities dealer whose work has been cited in several books by various scholars. But this is not the first time Oliver has come up with such outlandish stories. Oliver arrives at the Burdons' studio to find Susie and Arthur there. He tells them about his experiences in Alexandria, and explains how he came to know that nothing could possibly be certain. They are all very impressed by his ability to see things through a telescope, but they do not understand why he is interested in science so much when he has no real understanding of what it means to be an educated man. Oliver also relates some of his father's occultist-related happenings. In 1856, Alphonse Louis Constant, a French physician who had come to England as a missionary during the Civil War, was sent to England on a mission to discover the secret of the Transylvania slave trade. Upon arriving in England, Arthur meets Dr. Porhet, who takes him under his wing for a tour of the abbey grounds. The narrator notes that this tour lasted for only twenty-two days. During this time, both men have become familiar with each other. Haddo apologizes to Margaret for kicking the dog. Margaret tries to reason with him, telling him that he has no malice or intention for what he did. He merely looks at her and makes an inhuman smile. Margaret is astounded by Haddoo's apology but can do nothing to stop him from continuing his assault on Arthur. Margaret receives a message from Nancy Clerk asking her to meet them at the train station two days later. She meets Oliver in the middle of the night while waiting for the train. They begin talking about art and life together. Oliver tells Margaret that she must go to Paris because he wants her to marry him. Margaret cannot resist this temptation. She hurries to find out where they are married. Margaret begins to realize that her relationship with Arthur has changed. She no longer envisions him as dull and dull; rather, she compares him to the ravishing figure of Mr. Bulstrode. Margaret continues to make plans for their future together. One day, on a visit to Paris, she sees Susie's beautiful young maidservant sitting down by herself. The maid is so engrossed in her sensual beauty that Margaret can barely stand it. They go to St. Sulphice where they sit down to have a private chat. Margaret tells Arthur that she will marry him whenever he chooses. Arthur accepts this offer without hesitation. On his way home, he stops at Mrs. Bloomfield who informs him that Margaret has married Oliver. He realizes that Margaret does not love him but loves him anyway. In an attempt to clear up any misunderstandings, he invites Susie over for dinner. Afterward, he asks her to meet him in London. At midnight, after much discussion, they agree to meet there. Arthur asks Susie to come with him to see the opera. She agrees and they go out for a drink together. Arthur tells Susie that he wants her to meet his wife and son-in-law, who will be there on Thursday because of Tristan's upcoming visit. He invites Susie along as well. They all agree to meet in the opera hall. Arthur is so engrossed in his music that he can hardly stand it. Afterward, he takes Susie back to London where she has been spending most of her time with Margaret Haddon. Margaret becomes hysterical at the thought of being separated from her husband again. Arthur tries to help Margaret by asking her to visit the local doctor, Dr. Poyser. The doctor convinces Margaret not to go through with the divorce proceedings. Arthur then goes to England to try to track down Margaret. There, he finds her in a dilapidated old boarding house called Venning. Here, he learns that Margaret has been taken to an insane asylum. Arthur wanders around Skene looking for Margaret. He comes across a bench and sits down on it, pretending to be someone else. Margaret does not recognize him at first, but then she recognizes him as the Squire of Harlingen. Arthur explains that he has come to see Margaret because he is "flesh and blood" . She tells him that she wants to go with him so they can figure out how to kill him. They arrive in London just before dark, and are told that Margaret has died from an accidental drowning. The Squire asks them to let him know if there is anything suspicious about Margaret's death. Arthur agrees to help. But when he gets back to England, he realizes that he cannot do anything until he figures out who Margaret really is. So he goes to his lodgings where he meets Dr Porhomët , who also happens to be very close to Margaret herself. In this conversation, Arthur learns that Margaret had been poisoned three weeks earlier. This news troubles Susie greatly; she worries that Arthur will die without her knowledge. Meanwhile, Mr. Burlingen tries to convince Arthur that Margaret probably died from heart disease or some other mysterious ailment. Arthur refuses to listen to any of this nonsense. Susie is seized with anger at the cruelty inflicted upon her by Arthur. She moves forward and challenges him to tell them what he wants to do. He refuses, saying that they can either stay or go without him. After a brief period of silence, suddenly a woman begins weeping. The men are unable to understand what she is saying, so they try their best to think of something else to prevent her from going. They cannot figure out what it is that she is crying about. Susiedo tries to stop Arthur from speaking in Latin, but this only makes his voice even more stilted. Finally, Arthur agrees to come with them as soon as possible. When they finally arrive at Skene, they find an abandoned house full of ancient weapons, armor, and other objects. Arthur opens the door to the crawlspace, which leads right into the room where Haddos body has been hidden. Inside, Arthur finds a large pile of human hair on top of a broken oak door. There also appears to be a bloodstain covering the entire room. Arthur removes the bloodstained cloth and puts it back on the door knob. Then, he unlocks the door and peeks inside. A huge red-crowned creature laces its way toward them through the dark night air. It immediately begins to shriek and beat at the glass before returning to normalcy. Arthur hurries away, followed by Susie who follows after him. advertisement

title: Robur the Conqueror
target: The story begins with strange lights and sounds, including blaring trumpet music, reported in the skies all over the world. The events are capped by the mysterious appearance of black flags with gold suns atop tall historic landmarks such as the Statue of Liberty in New York, the Great Pyramid of Giza in Egypt, and the Eiffel Tower in Paris. These events are all the work of the mysterious Robur (the specific epithet for English Oak, Quercus robur, and figuratively taken to mean "strength"), a brilliant inventor who intrudes on a meeting of a flight-enthusiast's club called the Weldon Institute in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Members of the Weldon Institute are all firm believers that mankind shall master the skies using “lighter than air” craft, and that "heavier than air" craft such as airplanes and helicopters would be unfeasible. The institute has been constructing a giant dirigible called the Go-ahead, and are having a heated discussion of where to place its propeller (in front to pull it, or behind to push it) when Robur appears at the meeting and is admitted to speak to them. He chastises the group for being balloon-boosters when "heavier than air" flying apparatuses are the future. When asked if Robur himself has "made conquest of the air," he states that he has, leading to him accepting the title "Robur the Conqueror." During his short time at the Weldon Institute Robur so incites the members, that they chase him outside. Just as they are about to attack him, Robur appears to vanish into the mob, but he has actually been borne away by a flying machine. Later that night Robur kidnaps the Weldon Institute's secretary, president, and the president’s valet. He takes them on board his ship, a huge rotorcraft vessel called the Albatross which has many vertical propellers so as to operate similar to a helicopter, and horizontal propellers to provide lateral movement. It bears the same black flag with golden sun that has been sighted on so many landmarks, and the music in the sky is explained to be one of the crewmen playing a trumpet. To demonstrate the vessel's superiority, Robur takes his captives around the world in the course of three weeks. The president and secretary are angry at Robur for kidnapping them and unwilling to admit that the Albatross is a fantastic vessel, or that their notions of "lighter than air" superiority are wrong. They demand that Robur release them, but he is aloof and always says that they shall remain as long as he desires it. Fearing they will be held captive forever, the two formulate plans to both escape and destroy the Albatross. After the horizontal propellers are damaged in a storm, the Albatross is anchored over the Chatham Islands for repairs. While the crew is busy at work, the two Weldon Institute members light a fuse and make their escape. They try to bring the valet with them but cannot find him, only later discovering that the coward had escaped already without them. The Albatross explodes and its wreckage, along with Robur and his crew, plunge into the ocean. Meanwhile the three escapees are safe on a small but inhabited island and are later rescued by a ship, then make a long journey back to Philadelphia. The Weldon Institute members return, and rather than describe their adventures or admit that Robur had created a flying machine greater than their expectations of the Go-ahead, they simply conclude the argument the group was having during their last meeting. Rather than have only one propeller to their dirigible, they decide to have one propeller in front and another behind similar to Robur's design. Seven months after their return the Go-ahead is completed and making its maiden voyage with the president, secretary, and an aeronaut. The speed and maneuverability of the dirigible marvels a huge crowd, but are trivial if compared to Robur’s Albatross. Suddenly, out of the sky there appears the Albatross. It is revealed that when the Albatross exploded, enough of it was intact so that at least some of the propellers operated and slowed its descent, saving the crew. The crew used the remains of the Albatross as a raft until they were rescued by a ship. Later, Robur and the crew made it back to his secret X Island, where the original Albatross had been built. Robur has built a new Albatross and now intends to exact revenge by showing it is superior to the Weldon Institute’s Goahead. The entirety of the final scene is described from the crowd's point of view. The Albatross begins circling the Go-ahead; the Go-ahead drops ballast and rises to fourteen thousand feet. The Albatross follows, still a circling menace. The Go-ahead is at the mercy of the Albatross because the Albatross is both faster and more maneuverable. Finally, the Go-ahead exceeds her pressure height, where her gas bags rupture. Losing her buoyancy gas, Go-ahead drops out of the sky like a rapidly descending kite. The Albatross stays alongside of Go-ahead as she falls, signalling the pilot and passengers of Go-head to come on board the Albatross. They refuse, but then the crew of Albatross again seizes them and brings them aboard the Albatross. Having demonstrated his rule over the skies, Robur returns the three men to the ground. In a speech, Robur says that nations are not yet fit for union. He cautions the crowd that it is evolution, not revolution that they should be seeking. He leaves with the promise that he will one day return to reveal his secrets of flight.
pred: Robur the Confessor The narrator describes a series of events that take place during the course of June and July in order to illustrate the magnitude of the phenomena. First, the narrator explains, there are two men named Phil Evans and Jem Chip , who claim to have witnessed the phenomenon but do not elaborate on its cause or how they came to know about it. Second, there is an even bigger disagreement over the precise position of the object: whether the object is an aerial creature or simply a flying capsule. After much debate, the group finally decides to elect Robur as president. He gives a speech explaining his reasons for choosing the name "Robur" and then announces that he has invented a revolutionary aerostatic device called the Go-Airhead, which will enable people to travel beyond Earth's orbit by using electric motors instead of conventional ones. In other words, Robur is a complete coward. In the middle of nowhere, six armed men pound into the backs of Uncle Prudence and Phil. The Weldon institute sends out a search party to find them but no one comes to their aid. They are taken to a large open field with an oval field in which they sit down side-by-side on a plank. As soon as they begin to talk, however, there is a loud buzzing sound that sounds like someone preparing to attack them. Six more men rush across the field, two carrying Frycollins, two holding him down, and one dragging him off by his own hand. Soon enough, all six men have been seized and gagged. At this point, it becomes clear that Robur has also been kidnapped. In retrospect, we realize how important Robur's invention was for aeronautical engineering: He had originally planned to build a flying machine using wood instead of metal, but decided instead to design a mechanical bird rather than relying on electricity. This innovation greatly improves the efficiency of the avionics system. By the time Robur appears on the 24 th of June at 5:00AM, the airship has already left Philadelphia. Robur and the crew attempt to escape by jumping aboard a large, fast ship called the Albatross in June. They encounter a dense fog that prevents them from doing much of anything; however, Robur manages to maneuver the ship through it despite the danger posed by the approaching storm. In order to do so, they have to jump over several mountains and into the Indian Ocean during the course of four days. During these four days, they see nothing but beautiful scenery. After two days, Robur and his crew decide that they must blow up the airship. They decide to do so on July 24, the day before the scheduled launch date. The ship is uninhabited at this time, so Robur sends out a signal to the crew that they need to get going. They do manage to make it there in time, but things are not looking too rosy for their liking. On July 27, the group sees an island called X-Island with a population of about 3,000 people. title: Kim
target: Kim (Kimball O'Hara) is the orphaned son of an Irish soldier and a poor white mother who have both died in poverty. Living a vagabond existence in India under British rule in the late 19th century, Kim earns his living by begging and running small errands on the streets of Lahore. He occasionally works for Mahbub Ali, a Pashtun horse trader who is one of the native operatives of the British secret service. Kim is so immersed in the local culture, few realise he is a white child, though he carries a packet of documents from his father entrusted to him by an Indian woman who cared for him. Kim befriends an aged Tibetan Lama who is on a quest to free himself from the Wheel of Things by finding the legendary 'River of the Arrow'. Kim becomes his chela, or disciple, and accompanies him on his journey. On the way, Kim incidentally learns about parts of the Great Game and is recruited by Mahbub Ali to carry a message to the head of British intelligence in Umballa. Kim's trip with the lama along the Grand Trunk Road is the first great adventure in the novel. By chance, Kim's father's regimental chaplain identifies Kim by his Masonic certificate, which he wears around his neck, and Kim is forcibly separated from the lama. The lama insists that Kim should comply with the chaplain's plan because he believes it is in Kim's best interests, and the boy is sent to a top English school in Lucknow. The lama funds Kim's education. Throughout his years at school, Kim remains in contact with the holy man he has come to love. title: Antony and Cleopatra
target: Mark Antony – one of the Triumvirs of Rome along with Octavian and Lepidus – has neglected his soldierly duties after being beguiled by Egypt's Queen, Cleopatra. He ignores Rome's domestic problems, including the fact that his third wife Fulvia rebelled against Octavian and then died. Octavian calls Antony back to Rome from Alexandria in order to help him fight against Sextus Pompey, Menecrates, and Menas, three notorious pirates of the Mediterranean. At Alexandria, Cleopatra begs Antony not to go, and though he repeatedly affirms his deep passionate love for her, he eventually leaves. Back in Rome, a general brings forward the idea that Antony should marry Octavian's younger sister, Octavia, in order to cement the friendly bond between the two men. Antony's lieutenant Enobarbus, though, knows that Octavia can never satisfy him after Cleopatra. In a famous passage, he delineates Cleopatra's charms in paradoxical terms (rhetorical antithesis): "Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale / Her infinite variety: other women cloy / The appetites they feed, but she makes hungry / Where most she satisfies." A soothsayer warns Antony that he is sure to lose if he ever tries to fight Octavian. In Egypt, Cleopatra learns of Antony's marriage to Octavia and takes furious revenge upon the messenger that brings her the news. She grows content only when her courtiers assure her that Octavia is homely by Elizabethan standards: short, low-browed, round-faced and with bad hair. At a confrontation, the triumvirs parley with Pompey, and offer him a truce. He can retain Sicily and Sardinia, but he must help them "rid the sea of pirates" and send them tributes. After some hesitation Pompey accedes. They engage in a drunken celebration on Pompey's galley. Menas suggests to Pompey that he kill the three triumvirs and make himself ruler of Rome, but he refuses, finding it dishonourable. Later, Octavian and Lepidus break their truce with Pompey and war against him. This is unapproved by Antony, and he is furious. Antony returns to Alexandria, Egypt, and crowns Cleopatra and himself as rulers of Egypt and the eastern third of the Roman Empire (which was Antony's share as one of the triumvirs). He accuses Octavian of not giving him his fair share of Pompey's lands, and is angry that Lepidus, whom Octavian has imprisoned, is out of the triumvirate. Octavian agrees to the former demand, but otherwise is very displeased with what Antony has done. Antony prepares to battle Octavian. Enobarbus urges Antony to fight on land, where he has the advantage, instead of by sea, where the navy of Octavius is lighter, more mobile and better manned. Antony refuses, since Octavian has dared him to fight at sea. Cleopatra pledges her fleet to aid Antony. However, in the middle of the Battle of Actium, Cleopatra flees with her sixty ships, and Antony follows her, leaving his army to ruin. Ashamed of what he has done for the love of Cleopatra, Antony reproaches her for making him a coward, but also sets this true and deep love above all else, saying "Give me a kiss; even this repays me." Octavian sends a messenger to ask Cleopatra to give up Antony and come over to his side. She hesitates, and flirts with the messenger, when Antony walks in and angrily denounces her behaviour. He sends the messenger to be whipped. Eventually, he forgives Cleopatra and pledges to fight another battle for her, this time on land. On the eve of the battle, Antony's soldiers hear strange portents, which they interpret as the god Hercules abandoning his protection of Antony. Furthermore, Enobarbus, Antony's long-serving lieutenant, deserts him and goes over to Octavian's side. Rather than confiscating Enobarbus's goods, which he did not take with him when he fled to Octavian, Antony orders them to be sent to Enobarbus. Enobarbus is so overwhelmed by Antony's generosity, and so ashamed of his own disloyalty, that he dies from a broken heart. The battle goes well for Antony, until Octavian shifts it to a sea-fight. Once again, Antony loses when Cleopatra's ships break off action and flee – his own fleet surrenders, and he denounces Cleopatra: "This foul Egyptian hath betrayed me." He resolves to kill her for the treachery. Cleopatra decides that the only way to win back Antony's romance love is to send him word that she killed herself, dying with his name on her lips. She locks herself in her monument, and awaits Antony's return. Her plan fails: rather than rushing back in remorse to see the "dead" Cleopatra, Antony decides that his own life is no longer worth living. He begs one of his aides, Eros, to run him through with a sword, but Eros cannot bear to do it, and kills himself. Antony admires Eros' courage and attempts to do the same, but only succeeds in wounding himself. In great pain, he learns that Cleopatra is indeed alive. He is hoisted up to her in her monument, and dies in her arms. Octavian goes to Cleopatra, trying to persuade her to surrender. She angrily refuses, since she can imagine nothing worse than being led in triumph through the streets of Rome, proclaimed a villain for the ages. She imagines that "the quick comedians / Extemporally will stage us, and present / Our Alexandrian revels: Antony / Shall be brought drunken forth, and I shall see / Some squeaking Cleopatra boy my greatness / I' th' posture of a whore." This speech is full of dramatic irony, because in Shakespeare's time Cleopatra really was played by a "squeaking boy", and Shakespeare's play does depict Antony's drunken revels. Cleopatra is betrayed and taken into custody by the Romans. She gives Octavian what she claims is a complete account of her wealth, but is betrayed by her treasurer, who claims she is holding treasure back. Octavian reassures her that he is not interested in her wealth, but Dolabella warns her that he intends to parade her at his triumph. Cleopatra resolves to kill herself, using the poison of an asp. She dies calmly and ecstatically, imagining how she will meet Antony again in the afterlife. Her serving maids, Iras and Charmian, also kill themselves. Octavian discovers the dead bodies and experiences conflicting emotions. Antony's and Cleopatra's deaths leave him free to become the first Roman Emperor, but he also feels some kind of sympathy for them: "She shall be buried by her Antony. / No grave upon the earth shall clip in it / A pair so famous..." He orders a public military funeral.
